content.match_overview: Liverpool hosts Arsenal at Anfield as newly-crowned Premier League champions, fresh from a 5-1 demolition of Tottenham [1] but coming off a 3-1 away loss to Chelsea [6]. Arsenal arrives reeling from Champions League elimination by PSG and a recent 2-1 defeat to Bournemouth [5][7]. The Gunners have dropped 21 points from winning positions this season – the sixth-worst in the league – despite strong underlying xG numbers (+0.9 per 90 in +1 game states) [3]. Liverpool dominate recent H2H meetings, winning 4 of the last 5 encounters [4][7], with Arsenal's lone Anfield victory coming in 2012.

asian_handicap_analysis.analysis: Liverpool's -0.5 line at 2.05 offers value given their +1.93 xG difference at home vs Arsenal's -0.12 away [9]. The Reds have covered this handicap in 7 of their last 10 Anfield fixtures [6], while Arsenal failed to beat the spread in 4/5 recent away games against top-4 sides [7].
asian_handicap_analysis.raw: Liverpool's Expected Points (xPTS) of 2.68 vs Tottenham [1] dwarf Arsenal's 0.34 at Everton [10]. The Reds create 6.2 shots on target/game at home vs Arsenal's 3.8 away [6][7].

key_player_matchups.title: Mohamed Salah vs Myles Lewis-Skelly
key_player_matchups.content: Salah averages 4.7 shots/90 against Arsenal [4]. The 18-year-old Lewis-Skelly (2.3 tackles won/90 [14]) faces his toughest test yet at left-back.
key_player_matchups.raw: Salah needs 2G+A to reach 30G/20A – he's scored in 4 of last 5 vs Arsenal [4][11].

key_player_matchups.title: Virgil van Dijk vs Mikel Merino
key_player_matchups.content: Van Dijk (87% aerial duel success [6]) meets La Liga import Merino (1.7 key passes/90 [7]) in a clash of styles. The Dutchman's 300th PL game adds narrative weight [15].
key_player_matchups.raw: Van Dijk has 3 goals in last 8 games – Arsenal concede 0.8 headers/goal [8][16].

team_news.raw: Liverpool rest Alexander-Arnold for Bradley at RB [15]. Arsenal miss Gabriel (hamstring) and Havertz (hamstring) [8], forcing Lewis-Skelly into LB [14].

home.projected_xi: Alisson; Bradley, Konaté, Van Dijk, Robertson; Gravenberch, Mac Allister; Salah, Szoboszlai, Gakpo; Díaz [15]

away.projected_xi: Raya; White, Saliba, Kiwior, Lewis-Skelly; Ødegaard, Partey, Rice; Saka, Merino, Martinelli [14]

betting_insights.raw: Liverpool covered -0.5 in 80% of home wins; Arsenal failed 60% of away underdog roles [6][7]

betting_insights.insight: Over 2.5 @ 1.67 vs 3.1 xG combined last 5 H2H [4][6]
Mohamed Salah @ 2.10 – 6 goals in last 7 vs Arsenal [4][11]
betting_insights.raw: Salah averages 0.68 non-penalty xG/90 vs Arsenal [1][4]

prediction.reasoning: Liverpool's +1.93 home xG differential [9] should overwhelm Arsenal's depleted defense. The Gunners have conceded 2+ goals in 4/5 away games vs top-4 sides [7], while Liverpool average 3.2 goals/game at Anfield [6].

content.my_say: Anfield's red sea parts for one last league hurrah – a guard of honour for champions, a Trent Alexander-Arnold farewell tour, and Mohamed Salah chasing history against a patchwork Arsenal defense. The Gunners arrive as wounded animals, their Champions League dreams dashed by Kylian Mbappé's PSG just days prior. Yet Mikel Arteta's men cling to mathematical hope of pipping Manchester City to second – a pyrrhic prize that barely dulls the sting of another trophyless campaign. Watch for Liverpool's high-octane press to target Arsenal's teenage left-back Lewis-Skelly, whose baptism by fire could see Salah eclipse Thierry Henry's Premier League goal involvement record. In the shadows, Virgil van Dijk's 300th PL appearance looms large – a colossus facing his favorite opponents (4 clean sheets in last 5 meetings). This isn't just a football match; it's a coronation party meets autopsy, where legacy-chasing Reds confront identity-crisis Gunners. Bring popcorn.
